definition: goodbye

candidate_match.definition: goodbye
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Are you going? Bye then.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Bye, see you soon. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: Are you going? Bye then.
learner_examples: Bye, see you soon. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: used to mean 'goodbye'
dictionary_examples: "Bye." "Cheers, see you next week."
learner_examples: See you later, cheers. (Preliminary English Test; B1; )

definition: used to mean 'thank you'
dictionary_examples: "I've bought you a drink." "Cheers, mate."

definition: used to agree to a suggestion or request

candidate_match.definition: used to agree to a suggestion or request
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: "How about going out for dinner?" "All right." | "Can we leave at six?" "All right."
candidate_match.learner_examples: All right, tomorrow you get my jacket and wait for me at the bus stop. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

dictionary_examples: "How about going out for dinner?" "All right." | "Can we leave at six?" "All right."
learner_examples: All right, tomorrow you get my jacket and wait for me at the bus stop. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

definition: used to agree to a suggestion or request

candidate_match.definition: used to agree to a suggestion or request
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: "How about going swimming?" "Alright." | "Would you look after the children?" "Yes, alright."

dictionary_examples: "How about going swimming?" "Alright." | "Would you look after the children?" "Yes, alright."

definition: a friendly expression said just before you drink an alcoholic drink
dictionary_examples: Cheers! To your good health.

definition: used when you like something or agree to something

candidate_match.definition: used when you like something or agree to something
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: You've got your own apartment? Cool! | "We'll meet at ten, then?" "Cool."
candidate_match.learner_examples: That's very exciting. Cool! (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

dictionary_examples: You've got your own apartment? Cool! | "We'll meet at ten, then?" "Cool."
learner_examples: That's very exciting. Cool! (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: used to express anger or disappointment

candidate_match.definition: used to express anger or disappointment
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Damn! I've forgotten the tickets.
candidate_match.learner_examples: It was just a joke, damn it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

dictionary_examples: Damn! I've forgotten the tickets.
learner_examples: It was just a joke, damn it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

definition: something that you say when you want to congratulate someone

candidate_match.definition: something that you say when you want to congratulate someone
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: "I passed my driving test yesterday." "Congratulations! That's fantastic." | Congratulations on your engagement!
candidate_match.learner_examples: Congratulations on your wedding. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Korean)

dictionary_examples: "I passed my driving test yesterday." "Congratulations! That's fantastic." | Congratulations on your engagement!
learner_examples: Congratulations on your wedding. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Korean)

definition: something you say when you leave someone or when they leave you

candidate_match.definition: something you say when you leave someone or when they leave you
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Goodbye Marcos! See you next week.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Goodbye for now. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

dictionary_examples: Goodbye Marcos! See you next week.
learner_examples: Goodbye for now. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

definition: hello

candidate_match.definition: hello
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Hi, there! | Hi, how're you doing?
candidate_match.learner_examples: Hi Ramesh. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

dictionary_examples: Hi, there! | Hi, how're you doing?
learner_examples: Hi Ramesh. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

definition: used as a way of attracting someone's attention, or as a greeting

candidate_match.definition: used as a way of attracting someone's attention, or as a greeting
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Hey! What are you doing with my car? | Hey, are you guys coming to Angela's party?
candidate_match.learner_examples: Jesse: Hey, how are you? (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

dictionary_examples: Hey! What are you doing with my car? | Hey, are you guys coming to Angela's party?
learner_examples: Jesse: Hey, how are you? (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: something you say to someone when you meet them in the afternoon

candidate_match.definition: something you say to someone when you meet them in the afternoon
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Good afternoon, Cara.

dictionary_examples: Good afternoon, Cara.

definition: something you say to greet someone in the evening

candidate_match.definition: something you say to greet someone in the evening
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Good evening, everyone.

dictionary_examples: Good evening, everyone.

definition: something you say to greet someone when you meet them in the morning

candidate_match.definition: something you say to greet someone when you meet them in the morning
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Good morning, Joe - how are you today?
candidate_match.learner_examples: When you come in clas[s] he say[s] hi good morning every body. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

dictionary_examples: Good morning, Joe - how are you today?
learner_examples: When you come in clas[s] he say[s] hi good morning every body. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

definition: something you say when you leave someone or they leave you in the evening, or when you are going to bed

candidate_match.definition: something you say when you leave someone or they leave you in the evening, or when you are going to bed
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Good night, everyone - I'm off to bed.

dictionary_examples: Good night, everyone - I'm off to bed.

definition: used to greet someone
dictionary_examples: Hello, Paul. I haven't seen you for ages. | I just thought I'd call by and say hello.
learner_examples: Hello Fatima, how are you? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

definition: used to start a conversation on the phone
dictionary_examples: "Hello, I'd like some information about your flights to the USA, please."

definition: used when agreeing to do something or when allowing someone to do something
dictionary_examples: "Could you pick me up from the station?" "OK, what time?" | "I'll pay you back tomorrow." "Okay, no problem."
learner_examples: OK. See you for dinner! (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: used as a way of showing that you are going to take action, start speaking or start something new
dictionary_examples: OK then, if you're ready we'll start. | Okay, let's go.

definition: used to check that someone understands something or that they agree to something
dictionary_examples: So I'll get the food and you can get the drink, OK? | I'll see you at six-thirty, okay?
learner_examples: Don't forget to wear [an] old shirt and jeans, okay? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: introduces an idea that you have just thought of, or something that you have just remembered
dictionary_examples: Oh, I've just thought of a problem. | Oh, and don't forget to lock the back door. | Oh yeah, someone phoned for you while you were out.
learner_examples: Oh, and don't forget to show up in old clothes, ok? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: used to express different emotions, such as surprise, disappointment and pleasure, often as a reaction to something someone has said
dictionary_examples: "Jack can't come after all." "Oh dear, Emma will be sad to hear that." | "He's been married three times." "Oh, really? I didn't know that!" | "I'm afraid I can't come to the party." " Oh, that's a shame." | Is that for me? Oh, you're so kind! | "I'm sorry I forgot to ring you." "Oh, don't worry."
learner_examples: Oh, that's ok. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: used to express agreement with someone

candidate_match.definition: used to express agreement with someone
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: "Johnny, you climb up first." - "Right!"

dictionary_examples: "Johnny, you climb up first." - "Right!"

definition: used to make a request more polite

candidate_match.definition: used to make a request more polite
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Could I have two cups of coffee and a tea, please? | Please remember to close the windows before you leave.
candidate_match.learner_examples: We like Polish foo[d], so please make us something from Poland. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

dictionary_examples: Could I have two cups of coffee and a tea, please? | Please remember to close the windows before you leave.
learner_examples: We like Polish foo[d], so please make us something from Poland. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: used to politely ask someone to repeat something they have said because you have not heard it

candidate_match.definition: used to politely ask someone to repeat something they have said because you have not heard it
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: "You'll need an umbrella." - "Pardon?" - "I said you'll need an umbrella."

dictionary_examples: "You'll need an umbrella." - "Pardon?" - "I said you'll need an umbrella."

definition: thank you

candidate_match.definition: thank you
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Thanks for the advice. | Can you pass me that book? Thanks very much.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Hi, Thanks for your invite. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

dictionary_examples: Thanks for the advice. | Can you pass me that book? Thanks very much.
learner_examples: Hi, Thanks for your invite. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: used to tell someone that you are grateful because they have given you something, done something for you or made a polite remark
dictionary_examples: That was a delicious lunch, thank you. | "Here's your coffee." "Thank you very much." | Thank you for my lovely birthday present. | "You look very nice in that dress." "Thank you."
learner_examples: I like pork meat very much. Thank you very much. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin)

definition: said to politely accept or refuse something that has been offered to you
dictionary_examples: "Would you like some more cake?" "Yes, I will have a small piece, thank you." | "Do you need any help?" "No, thank you."

definition: used to show surprise, excitement, admiration, etc.

candidate_match.definition: used to show surprise, excitement, admiration, etc.
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Wow! Did you make that cake? It looks delicious!
candidate_match.learner_examples: Wow, this is very cool! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

dictionary_examples: Wow! Did you make that cake? It looks delicious!
learner_examples: Wow, this is very cool! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

definition: yes

candidate_match.definition: yes
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: "Do you like your job?" "Yeah, it's all right I suppose." | "Will you drive?" "Yeah, sure."
candidate_match.learner_examples: Yeah, try wearing black because we're gonna [get] dirty. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

learner_examples: Yeah, try wearing black because we're gonna [get] dirty. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to pause slightly or to express doubt or disagreement

candidate_match.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to pause slightly or to express doubt or disagreement
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: You'll go, won't you? - Well, I'm not sure. | Well, what shall we do now? | Who was that? - Well, I'm afraid I can't remember her name. | Well, after that we went camping in the mountains.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Well, my friend, I have just seen this film but I can see it again. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: You'll go, won't you? - Well, I'm not sure. | Well, what shall we do now? | Who was that? - Well, I'm afraid I can't remember her name. | Well, after that we went camping in the mountains.

definition: said as a greeting to someone arriving at a place

candidate_match.definition: said as a greeting to someone arriving at a place

candidate_match.learner_examples: Wendy, welcome to my town. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)
